text: (ethnic music)
- [Drew] I'm about to take
the most dangerous train ride in the world

across the West African
country called Mauritania
in the middle of the Sahara Desert.

Operating since 1963, the
train is over one mile long

and carries 17,000 tons of
iron ore on 200 carriages
every single day.
The track begins at an iron ore mine

in a small town called
Zouérat and goes 437 miles

across one of the harshest
environments on earth
to a little beach town called Nouadhibou.
Daytime temperatures in the Sahara
are well over 100 degrees,

and by night, it drops
down in the low 30s.
I have been a lot of places,

and I've done a lot of
things across 194 countries,

but this experience is unlike
anything I've ever attempted.
- Yeehaw!

- Also, I must admit that
I'm feeling quite exhausted,

because I've been on the road
non-stop for eight months.

Mexico, Egypt, Turkey,
Kurdistan, Dubai, Afghanistan,
Ghana, Tanzania, Ecuador, Venezuela, Iraq,

and now I'm capping off the
journey with Mauritania.

I came to this country
once three years ago,

but wasn't able to take
the train back then.

Just two weeks ago, my good
buddy Thomas from Yes Theory,
the same guy I went to Afghanistan with,
called me up and asked if I was interested
to do it together.
Obviously, the answer was yes.

We both flew from different
sides of the world

to Mauritania's fascinating
capital city, called Nouakchott.
I hope you guys are ready to hear about

potentially the craziest
adventure of our lives.
(dramatic music)
Very quickly, guys, I want to let you know
that my JUST GO European collection
just went live this morning.
The inspiration for the design

is all my favorite places
and landmarks in Europe,

because as you and I both
know, Europe is amazing,
and I wanted to celebrate that.
We only have 200 of these red t-shirts,
200 of the blue t-shirts,
and 100 of these really cool globe hats,
and it's first come, first served,
so click the link below in the description

for your chance to get
yours before they sell out.
And with that all being said,

let's head back to Mauritania
to the train story.
- [Thomas] Oh my God.
- [Drew] I was trying to start my GoPro!

- [Thomas] Dude, I
thought you abandoned me.
- No, no, no. How are you, man?

- How are you doing, bro?
- Are you all right?

- Yeah, I'm doing great.
- Okay, cool.
Thomas and I were hosted
at a friend's friend's family's house

who were so kind in
giving us a delicious meal
and a room to sleep in.

It's a pleasure to be in
the company of good people.
This is the tea.
- Merci beaucoup.

- [Drew] They also helped
us mentally prepare
for the journey of a lifetime.
- This is awesome. This is so...
I can't stop smiling.
- [Drew] Dude.
(ethnic music)
We hit the road in an 11 hour taxi ride.

I repeat: 11 hour taxi
ride, straight to Zouérat,
a dusty village in the middle of nowhere.

We just pulled over here,
because on Google Maps...

I checked my phone, and right
there is Western Sahara.
It's an unrecognized territory.
It's a place I really want to go.
Unfortunately, we don't have time really
to cross the border,

but it's one of those
countries that's like,

after you've finished
all 197 in the world,

the next tier would be those
unrecognized territories.
Finally, we arrived in Zouérat
and were told that the train started here,
but had no idea where to find it,

and we had 24 hours to figure
everything out by ourselves.
- [Thomas] We're sleeping here?

- [Drew] Are you serious? Oh
my God, we are sleeping here.
Holy smokes. Salaam alaikum.
- We're sleeping next to this guy.
- Bro, are we really sleeping here?
Like, are we actually sleeping here?

I've slept in a lot of places
in my life, but this one's...
I'm really getting out of my comfort zone,
let's put it that way.

- I'm so glad that you've
been to all of these countries
and that this is comfortable for you
and that I'm with you on it.
- At least we have this TV to watch TV.
This is like a full-on adventure now.
We've got to find food.

We've got to figure out how
to get around this place.
Luckily, Thomas speaks French fluently,

one of the national
languages of Mauritania.
- [Thomas] Bonjour. Ça va?
Ça va bien, et vous?

- [Drew] It's a skill
that I really wish I had.

- We're not the only ones
that have done this train,
but I don't think a lot of people
do what we're doing right now.
- Right.

Come here to hang out for
24 hours before the train.

There are definitely more
goats than people in this town.
I would bet my money on that.
(rhythmic drum music)
Pretty cool.

We met a local friend and
he's taking us around,

and that's really the
best way to see a city.
(they converse in French)

- He goes to school here,
but he lives in Nouadhibou.
(foreigner speaking French)

The town Nouadhibou, which is
at the end of the train ride,
where we're going tomorrow.
Says it's very pretty.
- [Drew] Have you taken the train before?
(they converse in French)

He says you meet people, you
make tea, you listen to music.
- [Drew] Amazing. That's so cool.
- He says it's a great time.
- [Drew] Awesome.

But not everyone had
the same opinion as him.
We're going to take the train.

- Train?
- [Drew] Train.

- You will take the train?
- [Drew] Yeah.

Well, it's very hard.
It's very hard. (chuckles)
- [Drew] Why is it so hard?
- To city is so far.
- [Drew] How many hours?
- Maybe 30 hours.
- [Drew] What? 30 hours?
- 30 hours.
- 30 hours? What?
Dude, are you serious?
We're starving.

We haven't eaten anything all
day except for like peanuts
and tuna fish in the car,

so we asked them to
take us to a restaurant,
and here we are.
- [Man] Salaam alaikum.
- Food has arrived. Eating with our hands.

- Yeah. There's plates come,
but there's no utensils.

- We haven't eaten all day, so
this is going to be a treat.
(they converse in French)
Zouérat!
Mauritania!
(downbeat ethnic music)
We have just left the house.
We got all these bags.

I think we're about to
cross the Sahara right now
on an iron ore train.
(downbeat ethnic music continues)
Oh my God.
- Holy (beep). That's the mine.

- This is something we
haven't really talked about,
but is this illegal?
- [Thomas] I think it's a gray area.

I don't think it's
allowed, but I don't think

that they necessarily try to
prevent people from doing it.
- Yeah, I think you're right,

because we're not paying
anything to get on it.
We're hitching a ride for free
across more than 1000 kilometers.
- Starting to get pretty nervous.
- Yeah. I feel nervous, man.
Oh my God.
This is about to be
probably the craziest 24 hours of my life.
(rhythmic drum music)

- We've no idea when the
(beep) it's going to leave,

we don't know how long
we're going to have,
and he also said locals just show up,

so we also don't know who
we're going to be with.

- So should we say goodbye
to these guys now, or?
- I think they're going to wait with us.

- [Drew] Hey, you're about
to take more pictures of us.
- [Thomas] He wants a photo.
- [Drew] Look at his phone case. (laughs)

Doing a little eating
before we get on the train,

because this is about
to be covered in dust.
We got tuna fish.
Tuna fish and a baguette.
- [Thomas] Where'd you get the tuna from?
- I got it from the store earlier.
(solemn percussive music)

So the train was delayed
like two to three hours,

so Thomas and I crashed
in this little house.

- [Thomas] One of the guys
said we should take these off.

He said it's actually forbidden
to have them on the train.
Because of how strong the wind is,

it's caught people and
flicked them off of the train.
- [Drew] Seriously?
- [Thomas] It's like a sail.
- [Drew] I actually kind of believe that.
The train is four hours late.

We've just been waiting in
this room. Flies everywhere.
How long is the train? 18 hours?
- [Thomas] 20 hours.
- You know what I just realized?

The world's longest
flight is like 17 hours,
from Sydney to London.

- I would definitely take
the world's longest plane
over this.
- It's going to be awesome.

(rhythmic percussive music)
(train horn blasting)

- Holy (beep). The train
has finally arrived.
- We've been waiting forever
and we're finally getting on this train.
It's arriving right now.

- It's going to be the
most brutal train ride
we've ever had,
but other than that, I'm very excited.
- Holy (beep)!

How are we going to sit
on top of the iron ore?
Look, it's still full!

Last moments on land before
jumping up on the train.
Get on! Dude, get on, get on, get on!
- Here, take it.

- [Drew] Dude, you're going
to get so (beep) dirty
as soon as you jump in here.
Oh, (beep).
Right now we're shaping the iron ore

because they wet it apparently,
so this is the only time
it's going to be a little bit bendable.
- How are you feeling right now?

- I'm feeling really
excited and really nervous,
both about 50%.
How are you feeling?
- I'm just excited to be honest.
I'm so (beep) happy to be here.
Merci!
He's just telling me, he's right there,

he's saying you gotta be
careful, because when it starts,

the whole thing is going
to jerk really (beep) hard.
There goes our guides.
- Bye-bye!
Oh, (beep).
(Drew and Thomas cheering and laughing)

- This is so amazing!
- We did it!
- We're already moving,

and oh my God, this is going
to be one hell of a trip, man.
Whoo!
(dramatic, energetic music)

- It's just sinking in how
dusty this is going to get.

- [Drew] We are the only
people on this entire train.

You can see the front
and you can see the back.

What kind of crazy (beep)
would do this, my friend?

I love pushing myself
out of my comfort zone,

and this is exactly getting
out of your comfort zone
and just doing what you love.
And this is an amazing moment.

I'm just so happy right
now to be doing this
with one of my best friends.
I got the goosebumps,

and it's just hard to talk
right now and share my feelings,
but this is just really freaking cool.
Okay, so I weighed all the options
and I'm going to pee in a bottle,

but I'm going to do it up there
in case I miss the bottle.
I don't want to pee on my bed.
- Drew's peeing on the iron ore train!

- [Drew] I didn't spill a
drop. I got every bit in there.

I'm going to save it for
when I gotta pee again.
- [Thomas] Just throw it out.
- [Drew] Why? I-
- [Thomas] No, no, no. Pour the pee out.

- [Drew] That was so
stupid, what I just did.
That was so (beep) stupid.
Oh, pour the pee out?
- [Thomas] Yeah.
- [Drew] What if it gets over my face?
- [Thomas] Lean over a little bit.

Just pick out where the
wind is going. Yeah.

- Holy (beep), dude! (laughs)
- Yeehaw!
- Nothing but Sahara for miles and miles.
- We're going very, very slow right now,
so we actually have a moment
to stand up here relatively safely
to just capture how ridiculous this whole-
- Bro, your face is still covered
in iron ore right now. (laughs)
- Every time you touch your face,
you just end up putting so much.
Do I have any on my face?
- [Drew] It's all over your face, man.
This is (beep) dangerous, bro.
- Dude, imagine getting-
- Anything happens to us right now,
we're basically dead meat.
- We wouldn't be able to let anyone know
if one of us falls off.

Like, how would we contact
the driver? Scream?
- [Thomas] This whole thing is shaking,

and it's very heavy, so
it properly whips you.
- I just want to take a moment and say,

dude, I'm so happy we're
doing this together,

and I'm so happy that
we have the opportunity

to make a cool story and
share it with the world.
It's just really special. Holy crap, man.
- (beep) crazy, dude.
- Dude, you're (beep) crazy, bro.
- You're insane.
- [Drew] Dude, both of us.
- [Thomas] I can't believe how much-
- [Drew] We feed off each other's energy
is what we do, you know?
The sun is going down.

This is our last few moments
of light for the next 12 hours,
and our last few moments of warmth.
There's people living right there.
Oh my God, my hand is so black.

We're coming coming to our
very first stop right now,
almost at sunset.
(soft xylophone music)
It's officially nighttime.
Eat some dinner.
We got nuts, brownies, water. (chuckles)
And bananas.
- It's getting wobbly and wonky.
It's going to be a long night.
- This is going to keep me nice and warm.
And the crazy part is,

we still have like 13 more
hours on this train. (laughs)

Even though I look so extremely
uncomfortable right now,
I'm having the best time of my life, bro.
It's 1:57 AM, I'm in my blanket right now,
and we literally just stopped.

I checked the map, and we
are nowhere near any towns.
Hopefully it's not a technical issue.

I really hope we're not
stuck here all night.
It's freezing outside.
Yo! Dude, it's almost morning.
- [Thomas] Are you praying?
- [Drew] No, I was just recording a video.
- [Thomas] Oh.
- [Drew] Dude.

- [Thomas] I thought you
were like a random dude.
- [Drew] What?

- [Thomas] I thought
you were a random dude.
- [Drew] Why?
- [Thomas] I don't know.
I thought you were sleeping

and then a random dude was
here praying or something.
I think I was dreaming.

- It's six o'clock in the
morning. I'm in my tent.
I managed to sleep a couple hours,
but I'm freezing cold right now
and we're waiting for the sunrise.

I am completely covered in
black. My breath stinks.

I can smell my breath
inside of this face mask.
Holy (beep).
- [Thomas] Good morning!
- [Drew] Good morning, dude. Sunrise!

- [Thomas] Sunrise is always
my favorite time of the day.

Everything is calm. The
world is just waking up.

And now to be in the middle
of nowhere, watching it...
When you climb to the top of a mountain,
it's so treacherous and challenging,

and then you get to the top
and you get to see the view.

That's exactly what
this moment feels like.

Because we started, and we
weren't surrounded by dunes,
beautiful desert like this.

So to wake up to that,
and with the sunrise,
feeling very grateful right now.

- I am completely
speechless at the moment.

Watching the sunrise in the
absolute middle of the desert.

The past 12 hours have
been complete darkness,
and very, very cold.
And I did sleep a bit,

but I kept tossing and
turning and moving my legs,

and I'd have to sleep
in the fetal position.

Even though we have six,
maybe five more hours left,

this is probably going
to be the best moment.
We did it, bro!
Almost.
At least we made it to sunrise.
Getting out of my blanket
for the first time in like 12 hours.

The sun is rising, and
we're rolling up to a town.
(Drew whooping)
(beep), man! Whoa!

First time we've see any kind
of civilization since Choum,
which felt like 10 years ago.
(warm guitar music)
(Drew sighs)
- We are
close,
maybe five to ten miles away.

It seems like the finish line
is just around the corner.
- [Thomas] Whoo!

- Oh my God. Please don't
fall, please don't fall.
Man.

- [Thomas] Holy shit.
- What an adventure.

Like, in every sense of
the word "adventure."
We... I don't want to say we did it.
We're almost there.
But it was such a great, great experience.
And it's really tough to see right now,
but right there,

you can see a guy standing
on top of the iron ore,
so there are other people doing it.
I think we're passing a dumpster!
(they groan)

- [Thomas] That was the
worst smell I've ever smelt.
- That was terrible.
I'm tasting poop.
- [Thomas] The ocean!
Whoo!

Oh, (beep).
- Holy (beep). Dude, it's moving already.
I jumped down at the last possible second!
Holy (beep), dude!
- What the (beep)!
- Oh my God.
It's hard to put into words
how incredible this experience has been,

and to share it with someone
so like-minded and adventurous
made it that much more memorable.

As tough as it was physically,
mentally, and emotionally,
the adrenaline rush is what we live for.

I encourage you to push yourself
out of your comfort zone,

because that's where you
may find your happiest self.
Thank you from the bottom of my heart
for watching this video,
and stay tuned for the next four episodes

as I take you deeper
inside Mauritanian culture,
lifestyle, and cuisine.
I'll see you next week.
(warm guitar music continues)
(water running)

- I've never been this
dirty in my entire life.
So much (beep).
(water gurgling)

- We just washed ourselves
in the bathroom of this cafe.
Thomas got his coffee.
Oh, yeah.
- So happy right now.
We feel semi-clean. Still really dirty.
My beard is covered in iron ore, but...
Able to change clothes,

and now we have a six hour
drive back to Nouakchott.

We did it, man.
- We did it.

- Unbelievable experience.
